prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Choice of law in the transferee court

para.paratext: One great concern of parties who have filed actions in a forum of their choice is the question of what law the transferee court will apply following transfer by the Panel. This question has come before the Panel in the form of an argument against transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 for the reason that transfer would affect the choice of law to be applied in the actions.

The Panel does not have jurisdiction to decide the question of choice of law, but has rejected the argument that it cannot order transfer. The Panel's decision in this respect is based on an assumption that the transferee court must apply the law of the transferor forum.[1] That the Panel would reject this argument against transfer should be especially clear where the transferee court has acknowledged in its decisions that it must follow the law of the transferor court's forum.[2]

The Panel has recognized that the transferee court will be obligated to apply the law the transferor forum would apply.[3] The choice-of-law rules were given a sharper edge by the D.C. Circuit in a 1987 decision. In In re Korean Air Lines Disaster of Sept. 1, 1983,[4] the court held that a uniform federal law could be applied, even in cases originally filed in circuits having divergent rules. The resulting rule depends on whether the cases are based on diversity of citizenship or federal question jurisdiction. In diversity cases, the court will apply the law of the transferor forum, by application of its choice-of-law rules.[5] For federal question cases, the courts should give close consideration to the transferor court's law, but that law is not binding on the transferee court; in that instance, the transferee is bound only by the law of the transferee circuit and the Supreme Court.[6] On matters of federal contract law and where federal law borrows state statutes of limitations, the law of the transferor court applies.[7] Courts have also declined to follow transferor circuit law where that law is unique or divergent from predominant interpretation of federal law.[8] Procedural matters are governed by the law of the transferee court.[9] If there exists a question concerning the appropriate law to be applied, it is decided by the transferee court, and not by the Panel.[10] The question of whether the court has personal jurisdiction is decided under the law of the transferor district, and looks to the contacts of the defendant with that forum.[11]

The choice of law requirements stand as a significant complicating factor in complex cases, whether class actions or Panel-transferred dockets. Changing the law to permit application of a single federal standard to apply to all cases would be one way to ameliorate the effect of the rule that sometimes results in numerous different rules of law being applied.[12] The problems with this simplifying approach, of course, is that it would affect the outcomes of many cases and would significantly increase the stakes of selection of a transferee district (and circuit). Under the current law, transferee courts must be attentive to allowing the MDL docket to proceed without compromising the substantive rights of the parties to have the appropriate substantive law apply to their claims and defenses. In one recent case, the court rejected an attempt to have a Master Consolidated Complaint and California substantive law apply in national class action litigation.[13] The court noted that this is especially important given the mandate that transferred cases be remanded to the transferor court for trial.[14]

One approach to streamline the process for tag-along actions is to allow parties to file later actions to be “direct filed” in the transferee district, without regard to whether venue would otherwise properly lie in that district. In one docket centralized in the Northern District of Ohio,[15] the transferee court entered such an order, and after the action had been pending in that district for coordinated proceedings, the transferee court transferred it to the Middle District of Tennessee, the district where venue would have been proper (essentially the same result as if it had been filed there initially, then transferred to the transferee court by the Panel as a tag-along action, and then remanded for trial). In addressing a motion to dismiss under Tennessee's statutes of limitation and repose, the court rejected an argument that Ohio's law would apply, as it was in fact the transferor court. The Sixth Circuit held that direct-filed actions that are then transferred to a more convenient forum for trial are an exception to the general rule calling for application of the law of the transferor court.[16]

The direct-filing stratagem is probably of decreasing value following the Supreme Court's refinement of the standards for personal jurisdiction in recent years. Of greatest impact is a trilogy of cases from 2017, which severely limits the number of states that may exercise general jurisdiction over a defendant.[17] These cases, coupled with the earlier Daimler AG v. Bauman decision, limit general jurisdiction to states where the defendant is “at home.”[18] Consent to jurisdiction in the transferee forum would also be a basis to permit direct-filed actions to stay in that court, but courts cannot properly require parties to waive their rights to defend cases at trial in a jurisdiction that can properly exercise personal jurisdiction.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 510 F. Supp. 1220, 1226 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Hanover, N. H., 314 F. Supp. 62, 63 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
See In re Plumbing Fixtures Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 756, 758 (J.P.M.L. 1972).

See, e.g., In re Plumbing Fixtures Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 756 (J.P.M.L. 1972), distinguished, In re General Motors Class E Stock Buyout Securities Litigation, 696 F. Supp. 1546, 1547 n.1 (J.P.M.L. 1988). See also Toll Bros., Inc. v. Dryvit Systems, Inc., 432 F.3d 564, 568 n.4 (4th Cir. 2005); In re General American Life Ins. Co. Sales Practices Litigation, 391 F.3d 907, 911 (8th Cir. 2004); In re Air Disaster at Ramstein Air Base, Germany, on 8/29/90, 81 F.3d 570, 576 (5th Cir. 1996), cert. denied, 519 U.S. 1028, 117 S. Ct. 583, 136 L. Ed. 2d 513 (1996).
829 F.2d 1171 (D.C. Cir. 1987), judgment aff'd on other grounds, 490 U.S. 122, 109 S. Ct. 1676, 104 L. Ed. 2d 113 (1989).

See, e.g., In re Volkswagen and Audi Warranty Extension Litigation, 692 F.3d 4, 17–18 (1st Cir. 2012); Anschutz Corp. v. Merrill Lynch & Co., 690 F.3d 98, 112 (2d Cir. 2012); Hayes v. Actavis, Inc. (In re Watson Fentanyl Patch Products Liability Litigation), 977 F. Supp. 2d 885 (N.D. Ill. 2013); In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 965 F. Supp. 2d 612 (E.D. Pa. 2013); Johnson v. Keybank Nat'l Ass'n (In re Checking Account Overdraft Litigation), 718 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (S.D. Fla. 2010) (applying Washington state law to decide enforceability of choice-of-law provision in contract); In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 489 F. Supp. 2d 932 (D. Minn. 2007). For a transferee court decision applying this rule and providing extensive analysis in the context of class actions with numerous transferor courts, see In re Fedex Ground Package System, Inc., 734 F. Supp. 2d 557 (N. D. Ind. 2010) (deciding choice of law issues as to Kansas plaintiffs) and 758 F. Supp. 2d (N. D. Ind. 2010) (deciding issues as to balances of transferor jurisdictions). See also In re Conagra Peanut Butter Products Liability Litigation, 251 F.R.D. 689 (N.D. Ga. 2008).

829 F.2d at 1175–76, 1180. This approach to choice of law for federal question cases has been followed in Devries v. General Electric Company, 188 F. Supp. 3d 454 (E.D. Pa. 2016), aff'd in part, vacated in part on other grounds, remanded, 873 F.3d 232 (3d Cir. 2017), cert. granted, 138 S. Ct. 1990, 201 L. Ed. 2d 246 (2018); Murphy v. F.D.I.C., 208 F.3d 959, 964–66 (11th Cir. 2000) (where federal law at issue, transferee courts are obligated to follow their own interpretation of the relevant law and the binding precedents of their own circuits, not conflicting interpretation of the relevant law binding on the courts in the transferor court's circuit), citing Campos v. Ticketmaster Corp., 140 F.3d 1166, 1171 (8th Cir. 1998), cert. denied, 525 U.S. 1102, 119 S. Ct. 865, 142 L. Ed. 2d 768 (1999). See also Newton v. Thomason, 22 F.3d 1455, 1460 (9th Cir. 1994); In re Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) Implants Products Liability Litigation, 97 F.3d 1050, 1055 (8th Cir. 1996); Murphy v. F.D.I.C., 208 F.3d 959, 964–65 (11th Cir. 2000), cert. dismissed, 531 U.S. 1306, 121 S. Ct. 849, 148 L. Ed. 2d 733 (2001); Bradley v. U.S., 161 F.3d 777, 782 n.4 (4th Cir. 1998); Menowitz v. Brown, 991 F.2d 36, 40–41 (2d Cir. 1993); Eckstein v. Balcor Film Investors, 8 F.3d 1121, 1126 (7th Cir. 1993), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 1073, 114 S. Ct. 883, 127 L. Ed. 2d 78 (1994); Conner v. Alfa Laval, Inc., 842 F. Supp. 2d 791 (E.D. Pa. 2012) (applying maritime law in transfer asbestos product liability cases arising from alleged exposure on U.S. Navy ships); In re Live Concert Antitrust Litigation, 247 F.R.D. 98 (C.D. Cal. 2007); Highland Tank & Mfg. Co. v. PS Intern., Inc., 246 F.R.D. 239 (W.D. Pa. 2007).

See Eckstein v. Balcor Film Investors, 8 F.3d 1121, 1126 (7th Cir. 1993), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 1073, 114 S. Ct. 883, 127 L. Ed. 2d 78 (1994) (each court of appeals considers questions of federal law independently and reaches its own decision, “without regard to the geographic location of the events giving rise to the litigation.”); In re United Mine Workers of America Employee Ben. Plans Litigation, 854 F. Supp. 914, 918–19 & n.7 (D.D.C. 1994); Eckstein v. Balcor Film Investors, 8 F.3d 1121, 1126–27 (7th Cir. 1993), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 1073, 114 S. Ct. 883, 127 L. Ed. 2d 78 (1994).
See In re Cardizem CD Antitrust Litigation, 332 F.3d 896, 912 n.2 (6th Cir. 2003), cert. denied, 543 U.S. 939, 125 S. Ct. 307, 160 L. Ed. 2d 248 (2004).

See In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., 260 F. Supp. 2d 722 (S.D. Ind. 2003). For a case analyzing, and ultimately applying the transferor court's law after concluding it was not a matter of procedure, see In Re Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation, 2007 WL 2172764 (D. Kan. 2007).

See, e.g., In re Helicopter Crash in Germany on September 26, 1975, 443 F. Supp. 447, 449 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Air Crash Disaster at John F. Kennedy Intern. Airport on June 24, 1975, 407 F. Supp. 244, 246–47 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
See, e.g., In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation, 742 F.3d 576 (5th Cir. 2014).
See Edward F. Sherman, The MDL Model for Resolving Complex Litigation if a Class Action is Not Possible, 82 Tul. L. Rev. 2205, 2217–18 (2008).
See In re Toyota Motor Corp. Unintended Acceleration Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 785 F. Supp. 2d 925 (C.D. Cal. 2011).
785 F. Supp. 2d at 930.
SeeIn re: Gadolinium Contrast Dyes Products Liability Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1380, 1382 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008).
SeeWahl v. General Elec. Co., 786 F.3d 491, 496 (6th Cir. 2015).

See BNSF Ry. Co. v. Tyrrell, 137 S. Ct. 1549, 198 L. Ed. 2d 36 (2017); TC Heartland LLC v. Kraft Foods Group Brands LLC, 137 S. Ct. 1514, 197 L. Ed. 2d 816 (2017); Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. v. Superior Court of California, San Francisco County, 137 S. Ct. 1773, 198 L. Ed. 2d 395 (2017).
Daimler AG v. Bauman, 134 S. Ct. 746, 187 L. Ed. 2d 624 (2014) (“at home” generally limited to state of incorporation and state where headquarters is located).
